head.title: Climate Change Makes Our Hurricanes Worse; Human Contribution

block.p: "From Uncle Smoke to Mr. Clean" by Gregg Easterbrook (Op-Ed, Aug. 13), on the Rio de Janeiro Earth summit accords, notes that the United States has indeed initiated a stronger follow-through on the treaty than our European critics at Rio.

"From Uncle Smoke to Mr. Clean" by Gregg Easterbrook (Op-Ed, Aug. 13), on the Rio de Janeiro Earth summit accords, notes that the United States has indeed initiated a stronger follow-through on the treaty than our European critics at Rio.

But Mr. Easterbrook also throws in the assertion that "since naturally occurring carbon emissions outpace man-made emissions by about 29 to 1, United States cutbacks would" have an insignificant effect. This comparison of naturally generated levels of carbon emissions with relative changes in those levels from human contributions misleads and confuses.

Global ecosystems have evolved a balance between levels of naturally generated carbon and the capacity to absorb carbon of "sinks" such as plants and oceans. This natural balance is threatened by human increases, however relatively small, of carbon and other greenhouse gas emissions -- mostly through our burning, in a geologic instant, of eons' worth of fossilized plants in the forms of oil, gas and coal.

A misunderstanding of the human contributions to carbon emissions hands a false but plausible-sounding argument to some who are more ideological and less thoughtful than Mr. Easterbrook. PHILIP C. METZGER Silver Spring, Md., Aug. 20, 1993
